Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 40117 
October 2006 
 
 
 
Free Trade Agreements in Asia: 
The Way Ahead 
(Financed by the Japan Special Fund)

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
FTA  –  free trade agreement 
GCGE  –  global computable general equilibrium 
LDC  –  least-developed country 
OREI  –  Office of Regional Economic Integration 
RCI  –  regional cooperation and integration 
TA  –  technical assistance 
WTO  –  World Trade Organization 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Industry and Trade 
Subsector  –  Trade 
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, regional cooperation 
Subtheme  –  Promoting macroeconomic stability 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Head      M. Kawai    Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) 
Director    S. Madhur     OREI 
 
Team leader    G. Wignaraja    Senior Trade Economist, OREI 
Team member  W. Paz     Senior Economics Officer, OREI

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Bilateral and subregional free trade agreements (FTA) increasingly are becoming major 
vehicles of trade policy and diplomacy among Asian developing member countries. However, 
little is known about (i) the impact of FTAs on business, (ii) the process of FTA negotiations, (iii) 
the economic effects of alternative FTA arrangements, and (iv) best practices in FTA design and 
negotiations. These issues lie at the center of economic policy debates in Asia on how to make 
FTAs stepping stones—rather than stumbling blocks—to multilateral liberalization through the 
World Trade Organization (WTO) process. In this vein, Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) President Kuroda, and other eminent persons have articulated 
a  vision  of  consolidating  and  deepening  bilateral/subregional  FTAs  into  an  Asia-wide  FTA 
covering all the major Asian economies.1 
 
2.  ADB has a solid track record in promoting regional cooperation and integration (RCI) in 
Asia. In April 2005, ADB established the Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) to 
facilitate and coordinate bank-wide RCI activities, with a focus on trade and investment as well 
as money and finance. RCI is a priority area in the Second Medium-Term Strategy, and trade 
and investment is a pillar of the RCI strategy. To promote a better-informed policy dialogue 
among stakeholders on trade and investment, OREI will prepare a variety of studies on FTAs, 
including  (i)  a  study  of  the  impact  of  FTAs  on  business  activity,  (ii)  case  studies  of  FTA 
negotiations, and (iii) a model-based study on the economic effects of FTAs. Further, OREI will 
develop a manual on designing and negotiating FTAs. This technical assistance (TA) paper 
reflects  the  purpose  and  output,  methodology  and  essential  activities,  cost  estimates  and 
financing plan, and implementation arrangements of this project.2 The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Before  1998,  the  only  significant  regional  accord  in  Asia  was  the  Association  of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Free Trade Area. The number of FTAs in Asia has increased 
dramatically since the late 1990s, however. ADB estimates that more than 175 bilateral and 
subregional FTAs have been signed or are being negotiated in Asia.4 East Asian economies, 
which are involved in 95 such agreements, have been the major driver of FTA formation in the 
region.  
 
4.  The coverage of trade and development issues in these agreements has deepened with 
the rise of the so-called second generation FTAs, which include merchandise trade, as well as 
services,  investment,  and  sensitive  issues  (e.g.,  intellectual  property  rights,  environmental 
standards, competition policy, and public procurement). Second generation FTAs also provide 
longer time frames for weaker countries to adjust.  
 
5.  FTAs are spreading in Asia for four main reasons:5 (i) dissatisfaction with the slow 
progress in global trade talks, (ii) defensive responses to activities of regional trading blocs 
elsewhere, (iii) the perception that international competitiveness and economies of scale can be

2   
achieved through FTAs, and (iv) the belief that FTAs can support a deepening of market-led 
integration in the region.   
 
6.  The spread of FTAs in Asia has positive and negative economic aspects. On the positive 
side, with global trade talks progressing slowly, FTAs can (i) promote continuing liberalization, (ii) 
induce structural reforms in the countries concerned, and (iii) widen market access across the 
region.  Trade  arrangements  with  dynamic,  internationally  competitive  partners  also  can 
encourage the spread of efficient production practices.  
 
7.  On the negative side, however, the formation of a large number of bilateral FTAs can 
lead  to  the  “Asian  noodle  bowl  effect”,  which  ADB  President  Kuroda  highlighted  following 
Professor Bhagwati’s initial observation of the “spaghetti bowl effect”.6 Multiple rules of origin 
(e.g.,  value-added  rules  or  changes  in  customs  classification)  arising  from  overlapping 
agreements  among  members  of  different  FTAs  can  have  harmful  effects.  Complex  rules 
increase administrative and business costs, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, 
which  have  limited  capacity  to  deal  with  them.  Such  rules  also  can  deter  foreign  direct 
investment  and  trade.  Further,  the  demands  of  negotiating  multiple  trade  agreements 
increasingly strain the scarce trade negotiation resources of many Asian countries, particularly 
the least-developed countries (LDC), which have limited trade policy capacity.  
 
8.  The dearth of high-quality, policy-oriented empirical studies on FTAs in Asia undermines 
the ability of policy makers to map the net economic benefits of FTAs for Asian countries (and 
businesses within them), assess trade-offs between costs and benefits of FTAs, and formulate 
appropriate regional/national responses.  
 
9.  A consensus is emerging among policy researchers that empirical studies are needed 
on important aspects of the spread of FTAs in Asia, including (i) the effects of FTAs on business 
activity;  (ii)  global  computable  general  equilibrium  (GCGE)  simulations  of  economy-wide 
impacts  of  FTAs  (e.g.,  economic  welfare,  sectoral  impacts,  and  wages  of  alternative  FTA 
scenarios); and (iii) the process of formulating FTAs through negotiations.7 The consensus also 
supports the need for identifying best practices in designing and negotiating FTAs to guide the 
process  of  forming  effective  FTAs  in  Asia  through  consolidation  and  deepening  of  trade 
agreements.  This  is  useful  for  ADB’s  capacity  building  assistance  for  developing  member 
countries. 
 
10.  In  line  with  ADB’s  mandate  to  be  proactive  in  facilitating/promoting  regional 
cooperation/integration in the Asia and Pacific region, ADB should assess this important trend 
through a series of FTA studies, and identify the future actions required to maximize the net 
economic benefit of these FTAs for member countries. The studies generated by this TA and 
the workshops will enhance the quality of policy dialogue on the economic effects (including 
poverty reduction) and the future shape of FTAs in Asia. Policy dialogue among better-informed 
stakeholders is likely to facilitate faster trade and investment integration in Asia. In turn, this will 
contribute to sustaining poverty reduction in the region through balanced or broad-based growth, 
employment creation, and social sector expenditures. Thus, the region’s trade and investment 
integration and poverty reduction processes are intricately linked with each another. 
 
                                                 
6  For a concise restatement, see Bhagwati, Jagdish. 2002. Free Trade Today. Princeton: Princeton University Press.  
7  These areas are the outcome of consultations with academics and policy makers at the recent Brainstorming on 
Free Trade Agreements, held at ADB on 20 March 2006.

3
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The intended impact of the TA project is increased knowledge and awareness—among 
policy makers in particular and the public in general—of the effects of FTAs on business activity, 
economic welfare, and trade negotiations, as well as best practices in FTAs. The expected 
outcome is a number of quality studies for promoting policy dialogue among stakeholders 
(governments, private sector, ASEAN Secretariat, and multilateral organizations) on how to 
maximize the net benefits of Asian FTAs.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  At the core of the TA project are three studies that focus on closely related aspects of 
the spread of FTAs in Asia.8  
 
13.  Business Activity. The first study covers the impact of FTAs on business activity. Such 
firm-level surveys do not exist for Asian countries. This might be due in part to the recent 
proliferation of FTAs in the region and the limited research attention given to analyzing FTAs. 
Accordingly, firm-level surveys of Asian countries, including possibly Japan, Singapore, Sri 
Lanka, and Thailand, will be conducted to document the micro-level benefits of overlapping 
FTAs (e.g., expanding market access and realization of economies of scale in production) and 
the costs (e.g., administrative/business costs from complex rules of origin). The results from the 
enterprise surveys of Asian countries will be used for a comparative analysis of the impact of 
FTAs on businesses in Asia and Latin America, which is being undertaken in close partnership 
with the Inter-American Development Bank and the Institute of Developing Economies in Tokyo. 
This type of unique comparative analysis at the firm-level will enable the collection of primary 
data, and provide original insights on business behavior under different FTA regimes.  
 
14.  FTA  Negotiations.  The  second  involves  case  studies  of  FTA  negotiations.  FTA 
negotiations, which often deal with goods, services, and a host of other issues, are becoming 
increasingly technically complex in legal and economic terms. Policy makers, particularly in 
LDCs, do not widely understand the process of such negotiations and their implications. Thus, a 
set of Asian case studies on successful FTA negotiations will be prepared for FTA negotiators, 
particularly from LDCs. Such case studies will examine (i) an inventory of regulations/future 
regulatory strategy, (ii) economic interests, (iii) negotiating strategies, (iv) expected and actual 
outcomes, (v) capacity issues, (vi) sectoral restructuring and adjustment, and (vii) lessons for 
LDCs.  
 
15.  Economic Effects. The third is a model-based study of the economic effects of FTAs. 
GCGE model-based analysis is useful for simulating the economic effects of the spread of FTAs 
in Asia using a consistent framework. This study will analyze alternative scenarios, including (i) 
the existing pattern of FTAs in Asia, encompassing a plethora of bilateral agreements and 
trading blocs; (ii) the consolidation of some agreements into larger regional and/or subregional 
agreements; and (iii) the eventual creation of an Asia-wide FTA covering all the major Asian 
economies, including possibly Australia and New Zealand. For each scenario, the study will 
shed light on their economic welfare, sector-level implications, and distribution effects, to the

4   
extent possible.9 The results will point to policy options that could enhance trade and investment 
integration in Asia. This study also will respond to Indian Prime Minister Singh’s suggestion that 
ADB study the benefits of such an economic agglomeration in Asia.   
 
16.  Besides being published individually, the three TA-supported studies will be inputs for 
the  preparation  of  a  fourth  overarching  study—a  best  practice  manual  on  designing  and 
negotiating FTAs. Meant for FTA negotiators, particularly those from LDCs, the manual will 
address important topics in new style FTAs. It will cover goods, services, investment, and 
sensitive issues (e.g., competition policy and public procurement). Further, the manual will 
provide guidance on designing model rules of origin, and negotiating strategies and tactics; and 
will suggest sources of information on trade, FTAs, and negotiations.   
 
17.  The results of these four studies will be disseminated widely through several modes, 
including publication as books, working papers, and policy briefs; and via policy workshops and 
seminars in Asia and internationally. The studies also will be posted on ADB’s Asia Regional 
Integration Center Web site. Where appropriate, they will be translated to permit wider use in 
the region.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $600,000.  The  Japan  Special  Fund,  funded  by  the 
Government of Japan, will finance the TA on a grant basis. The cost will cover remuneration, 
travel,  and  per  diem  for  international  and  national  consultants,  as  well  as  meetings  and 
conferences, publications, and other miscellaneous costs. A detailed cost breakdown and the 
proposed financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
 
19.  ADB  will  be  the  TA  Executing  Agency.  OREI  will  implement  the  TA,  in  close 
collaboration with other ADB departments and offices.  
 
20.  The TA activities will be implemented with the assistance of national and international 
consultants. The TA will require approximately 15 person-months of national consulting services 
and 11 person-months of international consulting services. The consultants will be engaged 
individually in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. The scope of work 
and outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3.   
 
21.  Four national consultants will be engaged to undertake firm-level surveys and case 
studies on FTA negotiations. The consultants will be experts on designing and administering 
firm surveys, and will have substantial knowledge of the concerned countries’ trade policies and 
procedures. They also should have a strong statistical background in data processing and 
analysis. In addition, three to four national consultants will be engaged to prepare country 
studies of FTA negotiations. These consultants will be experts on international trade policy, 
regional economic cooperation, and trade negotiations, and will have extensive knowledge of 
the bilateral or subregional FTAs being studied.  
 
                                                 
9  To maximize synergies with previous work, this study will build on the results of ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance 
for Long-Term Scenarios for Asian Growth and Trade, 2005–2020. Manila (TA 6205-REG, for $300,000, approved 
on 6 December); and ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance for a Study on Economic Cooperation Between East Asia 
and South Asia. Manila (TA 6282-REG, for $500,000, approved on 9 December).

5
22.  An international consultant will be engaged to prepare a model-based study on the 
economic effects of FTAs. The consultant will be an expert in the applications of GCGE, and will 
have substantial experience in trade and investment policies in Asia. Using the findings of the 
studies  prepared  by  the  other  consultants,  three  international  consultants  (a  lawyer,  an 
economist, and a negotiator) will be engaged to prepare a best practice manual on designing 
and  negotiating  FTAs.  These  consultants  will have  extensive  experience  in  designing  and 
producing a manual specifically for trade negotiators in LDCs.   
 
23.  OREI staff will participate as resource persons in all the components of this project, 
including field work, report writing, and presentations at conferences.  
 
23.  The TA is to be implemented over 17 months, from November 2006 to April 2008.  
 
24.  The  design  of  the  TA  project  has  been  discussed  with  major  regional/international 
organizations, and TA implementation will be coordinated closely with them. ASEAN senior 
trade  officials  and  academics  have  endorsed  ADB  support  for  carrying  out  special  issues 
studies (including analyzing the trade agreements that are the focus of this TA project) for the 
ASEAN economic ministers/senior officials’ process. ADB has set up an informal advisory group 
comprising  senior  trade  policy  makers  and  academics  from  the  region;  and  will  draw  on 
expertise from Asia’s think tanks, research institutes, and academic institutions. Further, ADB 
will  coordinate  closely  with  the  Inter-American  Development  Bank,  Pacific  Economic 
Cooperation  Council,  and  the  Institute  of  Developing  Economies  in  Tokyo  on  a  major 
component of the TA project—a comparative analysis of the impact of FTAs on businesses in 
Asia and Latin America. ADB also will consult the WTO during the preparation of the manual on 
designing/negotiating  FTAs,  and  will  work  with  the  United  Nations  Economic  and  Social 
Commission for Asia and the Pacific on data collection on FTA trends in Asia. The Organisation 
for  Economic  Co-operation  and  Development,  World  Bank,  and  WTO  will  be  invited  to 
participate in workshops conducted for the TA project.  
 
 
IV.  PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis for 
Free Trade Agreements in Asia: The Way Ahead, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
 
OUTLINE OF TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Consultants  for  the  Country  Case  Studies  on  the  Impact  of  Free  Trade 
Agreements (FTA) on Business Activity (national, 12 person-months; international, 3 
person-months) 
 
1.  The consultants will be experts on designing and administering enterprise surveys, and 
will have strong statistical backgrounds in data processing and analysis. The consultants also 
will have substantial knowledge of the country’s trade policies and procedures. In consultation 
with  Asian  Development  Bank’s  Office  of  Regional  Economic  Integration  (OREI),  the 
consultants will 
 
(i)  design a firm-level survey that accounts for the micro-level benefits and costs of 
the country’s FTAs, with particular emphasis on (a) transaction costs associated 
with rules of origin, trade procedures, etc.; (b) benefits derived from expanding 
market access, economies of scale in production, etc.; (c) investment decisions 
of  firms  (regarding  location,  products,  manpower,  etc.),  given  the  country’s 
bilateral and multilateral agreements; and (d) costs of paperwork to avail of 
preferential tariff rates; 
 
(ii)  supervise data collection fieldwork, data entry, and data editing activities; 
 
(iii)  convert survey data into standard and usable format (e.g., Stata file) for analysis 
and for submission to OREI; 
 
(iv)  prepare a technical report on the impact of FTAs on business activity in Asia 
using the survey data, including comparative analysis of the impact of FTAs in 
Latin America and policy implications; 
 
(v)  attend the inception workshop to discuss the more detailed terms of reference 
and to plan the work, a workshop to review draft papers, and a conference to 
present the final outputs of the study; and 
 
(vi)  undertake other tasks as required by the assignment. 
 
 
B.  Consultants for the Case Studies on FTA Negotiations (domestic, 3 person-months) 
 
2.  The consultants will have expertise in international trade policies, regional economic 
cooperation,  and  trade  negotiations,  as  well  as  substantial  knowledge  of  the  bilateral  or 
subregional FTA under study. In consultation with OREI, the consultants will 
 
(i)  prepare a policy-oriented research paper on the process of negotiating an FTA 
with the following components: (a) background information on the economic and 
political situation of the two countries, as well as their international trade policies, 
particularly strategies on FTAs; (b) features of each country’s negotiating process 
(e.g., in the US, Congress gives the President a negotiating mandate in the form 
of the Trade Promotion Authority, which contains the list of negotiating objectives 
that US negotiators must address); (c) assessment of the history of negotiations 
between two countries; economic models on which the agreement was based, if

10  Appendix 3 
any;  and  the  motivations/factors  that  led  to  the  formation  of  the  FTA;  (d) 
evaluation of the agreement (coverage and scope, provisions, sensitive sectors, 
etc.) and the distinguishing features of the FTA relative to other agreements of 
each country; (e) quantitative and qualitative assessments of potential gains for 
each country from the agreement; (f) issues raised during negotiations that are 
relevant for developing countries; (g) lessons learned and policy implications; 
and (h) comprehensive bibliography on the FTA negotiations; 
 
(ii)  draft background information, as required, for the preparation of the manual on 
best practices on FTAs; 
 
(iii)  attend the inception workshop to discuss the more detailed terms of reference 
and to plan the work, a workshop to review draft papers, and a conference to 
present the final outputs of the study; and   
 
(iv)  undertake other tasks as required by the assignment. 
 
 
C.  Consultant  for  the  Model-Based  Study  on  the  Economic  Effects  of  FTAs 
(international, 2 person-months) 
 
3.  The consultant will have substantial experience in trade and investment policies in Asia, 
as well as expertise in the application of global computable general equilibrium (GCGE). In 
consultation with OREI, the consultant will 
 
(i)  prepare a policy-oriented research paper that analyzes the economic effects of 
the spread of FTAs with the following components: (a) assessment of the pattern 
of bilateral and subregional FTA formation in Asia, including FTAs that are being 
implemented  and  negotiated;  (b)  estimates  of  the  benefits  and  costs  of  the 
proliferation of FTAs in Asia using the GCGE model, taking into account the 
assumptions and limitations of the model; (c) alternative policy scenarios and 
policy implications of each scenario; (d) evaluation of the potential benefits of 
consolidating bilateral and subregional FTAs into a single East Asia/Asia-wide 
FTA; (e) sector-level policy implications and economic welfare estimates of a 
consolidated FTA; (f) policy options and recommendations to enhance trade and 
investment  integration  in  Asia;  and  (g)  comprehensive  bibliography  on  the 
economic effects of FTAs in Asia; 
 
(ii)  draft background information, as required, for the preparation of the manual on 
best practices on FTAs using the findings of the study; 
 
(iii)  attend the inception workshop to discuss the more detailed terms of reference 
and to plan the work, a workshop to review draft papers, and a conference to 
present the final outputs of the study; and 
 
(iv)  undertake other tasks as required by the assignment.

Appendix 3  11 
D.  Consultant  for  the  Best  Practice  Manual  on  Designing  and  Negotiating  FTAs 
(international, 6 person-months) 
 
4.  The consultant will have substantial experience in designing and producing a manual 
specifically for trade negotiators from least-developed countries (LDC). In consultation with 
OREI, the consultant will 
 
(i)  prepare a high-quality, publishable manual with the following components: (a) 
review of best practice principles on FTA design; (b) assessment of effective 
FTAs  in  Asia  that  embody  World  Trade  Organization-compatible  norms;  (c) 
overview of multilateral rules for FTAs, particularly on trade in goods, trade in 
services, rules of origin, government procurement, etc.; (d) overview of sensitive 
issues in trade negotiations that are relevant for LDCs, such as competition 
policy,  public  procurement,  etc.;  (e)  basic  technical  requirements  for  FTA 
negotiators (e.g., analytical skills, knowledge of international trade policies, etc.); 
(f) discussion of the negotiating process and guidelines for negotiators (e.g., 
strategies,  tactics,  etc.);  (g)  pointers  for  drafting  an  agreement,  including 
designing  new  style  FTAs,  model  rules  of  origin,  etc.;  and  (h)  sources  of 
information on trade, FTAs, and negotiations; 
 
(ii)  use the findings from the country case studies on the impact of FTAs, the case 
studies on FTA negotiations, and the model-based study on economic effects of 
FTAs provided by other consultants in the project, as necessary; 
 
(iii)  attend the inception workshop to discuss the more detailed terms of reference 
and to plan the work, a workshop to review draft papers, and a conference to 
present the final outputs of the study; and 
 
(iv)  undertake other tasks as required by the assignment.
